Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Combined Theoretical/Experimental Approach to Understanding Irradiation-Induced Morphology Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: The irradiation of solid materials with ion beams holds great promise for shape and surface control in materials processing at the nanoscale. When materials are irradiated by ions at sufficiently low energies that the ions don't penetrate into the bulk but rather stay near the surface, several interesting phenomena are observed. Certain irradiation conditions lead to ultra-smoothing, which has important potential applications in fields ranging from X-ray optics to light trapping devices to surgery tools. Under other conditions, one observes self-organized arrays of nanoscale surface ripples, mounds, or pits, with potential applications in fields such as optoelectronics. Although both phenomena are potentially rich sources of technological applications, currently the fundamental physical mechanisms determining ultra-smoothing or self-organized behavior are not well understood. The project is a tightly-integrated experimental (Harvard University) and theoretical (Southern Methodist University) study of the fundamental physical principles governing nanoscale morphology evolution during ion irradiation. The research activities are integrated with educational activities to train graduate students in nanoscience and nanotechnology.

Technical Description: This collaborative project explores the fundamental physical mechanisms of both the nanoscale topographic pattern formation by a high energy ion beam at a glancing incident angle, and the ultra-smoothing using low energy ion beam irradiation. The ultimate goal is to develop deep understanding and theory that could predict the outcome of arbitrary irradiation conditions. An important aspect of the project is the combined experimental approach and atomistic simulation to identify individual (nano-scale) ion impacts and correlate them with observed (macro-scale) morphological evolution. On one hand, a new multi-scale theoretical framework promises the ability to identify, via atomistic simulation, the atomistic origin of continuum effects such as stress. On the other hand, access to versatile experimental facilities allows measuring the continuum behavior and the critical material properties and testing theoretical predictions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of energetic ion beams has great promise for controlling the shape of materials features when synthesizing or processing materials with feature sizes too small for standard fabrication techniques.  When materials are irradiated at energies low enough that the principal phenomena are observed at the surface rather than in the bulk after penetrating the surface, several interesting phenomena are observed.  Under certain irradiation conditions, ion beams lead to ultra-smoothing, which has important potential applications in fields ranging from X-ray optics to communication signals to surgery.  Under other conditions, one observes self-organized arrays of nanoscale surface features, with potentially unique applications to electronics, optoelectronics, or spintronics. In nuclear fission power plants, as well as future radiation-free nuclear fusion power plants, the behavior of materials under irradiation is a major limitation on the performance of the plant; this has become an important consideration for reactor design. Although both ultra-smoothing and self-organized nanoscale feature formation are potentially rich sources of technological application, the fundamental physical mechanisms determining behavior had not been well understood.  The research performed under this award was a tightly-integrated experimental and theoretical study of the fundamental physical principles governing surface shape evolution during ion irradiation.  The understanding developed will enable a greatly enhanced degree of control of the behavior of materials under irradiation.

     The project was unique in its simultaneous use of experiment, theory, and computer simulation of the trajectories of individual atoms in order to identify, model, and verify connections between individual (nano-scale) ion impacts, as illustrated in the upper left of the accompanying image, and observed (large-scale) morphological evolution, as illustrated in the other parts of the image.  The research identified conditions under which expensive and specialized computer simulations can be replaced by simple ion beam simulation packages broadly available to the R&D community, and still yield results consistent with experimental results.

     In a discovery aiding the application to materials fabrication, we found that when the surface is steeper (with respect to the direction of the incoming ion beam) than a certain critical slope, it can dynamically evolve to something that is much smaller in scale and more difficult to make directly than the initial pattern that we had machined into the surface. We found that the evolution of steep features follows the mathematical description of a shock front, and that the spatial evolution of the shock front could be predicted with a simple curve evolution equation. Solving such equations is fast, so it naturally leads to efficient methods to solve the “inverse design” problem of determining how to pattern the surface initially so it evolves to a desired target structure. We showed how to make a simple lattice connecting diamonds with steep ridges, but it is easy to imagine making more complex patterns. This inverse design problem is common in many disciplines of science and engineering, and parts of the approach that we have developed are generalizable to other disciplines.

     The most significant fundamental outcome of this work is that we have been able to quantitatively distinguish between mechanisms involving ion-induced sputtering (kicking atoms out of the material), ion-induced mass transfer (kicking atoms around so they land in different positions within the material), ion-induced swelling and stress generation, and irradiation-enhanced viscous flow and surface diffusion in pattern formation. The research community has been having this debate about the relative strength of these effects for two decades. We found that material behavior can be explained well by models of swelling, anisotropic stress generation, and viscous flow. Our results show that the effect of stress accumulation is approximately a factor of 10 greater than the effect of sputtering and mass redistribution.

     One female Ph.D. student was trained on focused and diffuse ion beam and X-ray scattering experimental techniques and modeling and simulation techniques. She learned to design, execute, and report her own research projects. She completed her Ph.D. at Harvard and has now taken a position in U.S. industry. Additionally, the training of one postdoc was supported part-time; he is about to start a faculty position at a U.S. university.
